result.execSummary:
The defendant Steven T Szymkowski was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Criminal Trespass to Dwelling, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.14.
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

--no contact with any other known drug offender, except for treatment purposes as allowed by the Agent, and except for incidental contact for employment and education purposes as allowed by the Agent
--to obtain/maintain fulltime employment and/or education program as approved by the Agent
The Court notes that if the DOC seeks to terminate Probation early, the State has indicated it has no opposition to that.

Arresting Agency: PAPD

  If probation, parole or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of the victim(s) and government entities for the balance due.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Steven T Szymkowski

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: With elements and criminal case settlement agreement forms attached.

[Clerk: MK]
case called at 8:45am. 
Defendant Steven T Szymkowski in court with Attorney David Zarwell.  ADA Theresa Beck appears for the State of Wisconsin.    

On Motion of the State, the Courts amends the single felony charge to two misdemeanor charges:
--Count #1:  Class A Misdemeanor Criminal Trespass to a Dwelling, contrary to St. 943.14
--Count #2:  Class B Misdemeanor Disorderly Conduct, contrary to St. 947.01(1) 

Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights given; plea of " No Contest " entered on Counts #1, #2; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified (ADA Beck indicates that there is no victim imput and no restitution request); the Court accepts the pleas, finds Mr. Szymkowski guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

On both counts, the Court withholds sentence, and places Mr. Szymkowski on Probation for two years, with conditions:

--to undergo AODA assessment; this assessment must occur or at least be scheduled within 90 days; and to follow through with all recommended treatment
--to undergo any other assessment, treatment, and counseling as deemed appropriate by the Agent
--to maintain absolute sobriety:  no possession or consumption of alcohol; no possession or consumption of controlled substances without a valid prescription
--to take all prescribed medications as prescribed
--no acts or threats of violence
--no direct or indirect contact with Jamie Koutsky
--no presence at or within 1000 feet of the residence of Jamie Koutsky, currently 303 N. 1st Street in the Village of Palmyra, except for the sole purpose of traveling to or from employment 
--no contact with any other known drug offender, except for treatment purposes as allowed by the Agent, and except for incidental contact for employment and education purposes as allowed by the Agent
--to obtain/maintain fulltime employment and/or education program as approved by the Agent
--to pay costs of $243 plus $200 DNA surcharge on each count ($886 total) 


Days credit for time already served:  0 days
Contact prohibition warnings/penalties are given. 
The Court does not authorize expungement, given the fact that the serious felony was amended to misdemeanors. 
The Court notes that if the DOC seeks to terminate Probation early, the State has indicated it has no opposition to that.

The Court indicates that if the DNA surcharge is found to be unconstitutional, and the Defendant has not yet paid the surcharge, then the Judgment of Conviction is to be amended to remove the surcharge payment requirement.  If the DNA surcharge has been paid and the ruling that found the DNA surcharge unconstitutional directs the clerks to reimburse the amount paid, then the clerk is to refund the amount paid to the Defendant. If the reimbursement is not mandated, then the amount will be kept.
recess 8:59am.
Preliminary hearing on June 23, 2014 at 08:30 am.
Pre-trial conference on June 4, 2014 at 02:00 pm.

Case called at 1:04 pm 
Defendant Steven T Szymkowski in court with Attorney David Zarwell. ADA Brookellen Teuber appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Service of Complaint admitted; reading waived; maximum penalties recited
Preliminary Hearing time limits waived upon agreement of parties 

Court requires a $5000 signature bond, with conditions:
-No direct or indirect contact with Jamie Koutsky, Pat Maloney, Scott Pavlak or Joseph Merryfield
(Direct or indirect contact prohibitions include but are not limited to phone calls, letters, emails, texts, social media, other electronic means and no one can contact the person on your behalf except an attorney.) 
-No presence at the residence of Jamie Koutsky
-No possession or consumption of controlled substances without a valid prescription 
-Booking at JCSD 

Court verfies dob and spelling of name is correct on the complaint; Def. provides new address

NEXT: (1) DA Pre-trial Conference scheduled for 6/4/14 at 2:00 pm - Send notices (2) Schedule Preliminary Hearing 2-3 weeks after DA PTC - Send notices
